events.title: Birth of Ottorino Respighi
events.summary: Respighi was born in Bologna to a middle-class family with musical influences. His father's encouragement, despite Respighi's initial disinterest in music, shaped his early years.
events.fun_version: Born in Bologna to a middle-class family with musical influences, Respighi entered the world like a musical superhero, fame-bound but initially ghosting the whole music scene. But fear not! His dad, the ultimate musical cheerleader, turned that baby disinterest into melodic mayhem – talk about a plot twist!

events.title: Diploma in Violin Performance
events.summary: In June 1899, Respighi received his diploma in violin performance, successfully performing a piece by Paganini during his examination.
events.fun_version: In June 1899, Respighi proudly received his diploma in violin performance, taking the stage and mastering a Paganini piece like a boss, surprising everyone, including himself, who thought he’d just come to play the washboard!

events.title: Principal Violist in Saint Petersburg
events.summary: In the winter of 1900, Respighi accepted the role of principal violist in the orchestra at the Russian Imperial Theatre, where he met the composer Rimsky-Korsakov, who provided him with composition lessons.
events.fun_version: So there was Respighi, braving the winter of 1900 like a true hero, signing up as the principal violist at the Russian Imperial Theatre. Little did he know, he'd meet the legendary Rimsky-Korsakov there—basically his musical Yoda, who provided him with invaluable composition lessons!

events.title: Final Exam Successful Performance
events.summary: Respighi performed his composition 'Preludio, corale e fuga' in June 1901 as part of his final exam at the Liceo Musicale, which received a resounding success and acclaim from his instructors.
events.fun_version: In June 1901, Respighi debuted his composition 'Preludio, corale e fuga' during his final exam at the Liceo Musicale. His performance not only earned a round of applause but also received resounding success and acclaim, with instructors even considering giving him extra credit for not using a kazoo!

events.title: First International Success
events.summary: Respighi's transcription of Monteverdi's 'Lamento d'Arianna' premiered in Berlin in 1908, marking his first significant success on an international stage.
events.fun_version: So, Respighi walks into a Berlin auditorium in 1908 with a transcription of Monteverdi's 'Lamento d'Arianna,' and the crowd goes wild! BOOM! He's an international superstar—his first significant success on an international stage and a stellar attempt at making the classics trendy!

events.title: Premier of the Opera Semirâma
events.summary: Respighi's second opera, Semirâma, premiered at the Teatro Comunale in November 1910, receiving critical acclaim and marking a notable shift in his musical style.
events.fun_version: Respighi's second opera, Semirâma, hit the stage at the Teatro Comunale in November 1910, receiving critical acclaim and marking a notable shift in his musical style, much to the delight of critics who finally realized that opera is just an extremely long way to deliver a message!

events.title: Premiere of Fountains of Rome
events.summary: In March 1917, Respighi's first orchestral tone poem, 'Fountains of Rome,' premiered in Rome, setting the stage for his rising fame in the classical music world.
events.fun_version: In March 1917, Respighi’s first orchestral tone poem, 'Fountains of Rome,' premiered in Rome. It was such a hit that the fountains have been overflowing ever since, probably wondering why no one brought them along for the concert! This marked the beginning of Respighi's rising fame in the classical music world.

events.title: Marriage to Elsa Olivieri-Sangiacomo
events.summary: Respighi married 19-year-old Elsa Olivieri-Sangiacomo in January 1919, marking the beginning of a deeply harmonious relationship shared through their love of music.
events.fun_version: Respighi tied the knot with the 19-year-old Elsa Olivieri-Sangiacomo in January 1919, marking the start of a deeply harmonious relationship, a symphony of love that was so harmonious it could make even the grumpiest cat tap its paws in rhythm!

events.title: Debut at Carnegie Hall
events.summary: In December 1925, Respighi made his American debut at Carnegie Hall, conducting and performing his own works, which propelled his recognition internationally.
events.fun_version: In December 1925, Respighi made his American debut at Carnegie Hall, conducting and performing his own works, which propelled his recognition internationally faster than your uncle at a family gathering can tell a bad joke!

events.title: Premiere of Roman Festivals
events.summary: 'Roman Festivals,' Respighi's third Roman tone poem, was premiered at Carnegie Hall in February 1929, solidifying his status as a leading composer of his time.
events.fun_version: Roman Festivals, Respighi's third Roman tone poem, had its grand premiere at Carnegie Hall in February 1929. They say it was so good that even the statues in Rome stopped photobombing and started clapping!

events.title: Final Work on Opera Lucrezia
events.summary: Respighi fell ill while working on his opera Lucrezia at the end of 1935. Though he had made significant progress, he was unable to complete it due to health issues.
events.fun_version: Respighi was so committed to finishing his opera, Lucrezia, that he decided to fall ill halfway through—because what better way to create tension than by starring in a real-life opera of his own? It seems like his health decided to go on an unexpected solo! Unfortunately, despite making significant progress, he was unable to complete it due to these health issues.

events.title: Death of Ottorino Respighi
events.summary: Respighi passed away on April 18, 1936, in Rome after a prolonged illness that led to complications, marking the end of a significant era in classical music.
events.fun_version: Respighi checked out of this world on April 18, 1936, in Rome, but not without a dramatic farewell with complications! Although we have lost a composer, Respighi's legacy marked the end of a significant era in classical music, and his encore still echoes in the concert halls!

works.title: String Quartet in D minor, P.91
Antiche danze et arie per liuto, Suite No.1
4 Liriche su parole di poeti armeni
Antiche danze et arie per liuto, Suite No.2
